topic: Deep dive: _sitebuiltins standard library module in Python 3.12+
prompt: Write a Python 3.12+ focused, accurate explainer for: Deep dive: _sitebuiltins standard library module in Python 3.12+

response_parsed.title: Deep Dive: _sitebuiltins Standard Library Module in Python 3.12+
response_parsed.summary: This explainer delves into the _sitebuiltins standard library module, a critical component of Python 3.12+ that provides essential built-in objects and functions.
key_points: Introduced in Python 3.12, _sitebuiltins offers improved compatibility between CPython and other implementations
It contains many built-in objects like AbsFuncBase, Buffer, CodeType, FrameType, etc.
Using _sitebuiltins can aid in writing more portable code by reducing reliance on global built-ins
Certain functions and classes in _sitebuiltins are only accessible within the main thread or in extension modules

code_examples.code:
from _sitebuiltins import AbsFuncBase, Buffer
print(AbsFuncBase, Buffer)

version_notes: _sitebuiltins is only available in Python 3.12 and later versions.
It's essential to be aware of the differences between built-in objects provided by _sitebuiltins and those from traditional global built-ins.
caveats: Directly using _sitebuiltins can lead to obscure code that may be difficult for others to understand
It's generally recommended to rely on standard built-ins, unless there is a specific need for cross-implementation compatibility
